Take advantage of special grocery-store hours Link: http://newsok.com/article/5658120 Coronavirus in Oklahoma: Corrections Department stops accepting inmates from jails Link: http://newsok.com/article/5658121 Coronavirus in Oklahoma: Tenants, landlords and bankers scrambling to survive pandemic's economic ruin Link: http://newsok.com/article/5658122 Coronavirus in Oklahoma: Plaza District in OKC is 'quieter' after restrictions Link: http://newsok.com/article/5658114 Coronavirus in Oklahoma: Law enforcement adjusts procedures to keep officers safe Link: http://newsok.com/article/5658115

Those who are elderly or have pre-existing medical conditions are most at risk with COVID-19, so battling crowds of shoppers to pick up groceries or medications can be especially daunting.

Dennis Maxwell, head of marketing for the Oklahoma-based company Homeland, said that’s why he implemented specialty hours at all Homeland locations.

“We have a responsibility not only for our health but for those of us that may be in the high-risk group,” Maxwell said. “We have an opportunity to provide a space for people who are at high risk to shop where they are not congested and they feel a little bit safer to get the items they need.”

On Tuesday, Gov. Kevin Stitt said many grocery stores were committed to leaving the first hour of operation open for those who need to take additional precautions.

“So if you are healthy, please wait until later in the day to buy your groceries,” Stitt said.

That first hour is when stores are likely to be best stocked and most clean, Maxwell said.

No single place lists which grocery stores are participating and exact hours, so individuals will need to call ahead to their grocery store of choice.

At Homeland, store employees won’t be screening people who come in, so Maxwell is relying on the “Oklahoma Standard” for accountability.

“I believe in the Oklahoma Standard and that the people will band together to help provide safety to those who need it most,” he said. “I think once people get educated that we are reserving those hours, we’ll be able to do this.”

Walmart stores will also be providing specialty hours every Tuesday morning from March 24 to April 28, according to Walmart officials.

Most Walmart stores are operating on adjusted hours of 7 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. The pharmacy and vision centers will be open.

Dollar General also announced it was “strongly encouraging” stores to save the first hour of shopping for those most at risk.

Some stores across the metro area said they did not have specialty hours in place when asked. This included locations like Crest, Buy For Less and Sprouts.

Ron Edgmon, Oklahoma Grocers Association president, said the move is voluntary but stores are “responding well.”

“Our industry prides ourselves on serving the community, so this was a natural step to continue doing just that,” Edgmon said in an email.

“I applaud the hard work and commitment of Oklahoma’s independent grocers to their communities during this trying time.”

Other community members, like those at Cornerstone United Methodist Church, are also adjusting to help elderly or compromised neighbors.

“Our church has put together a team that is on call just in case one of our at-risk members would need us to run errands for them to get groceries or pick up medication,” Pastor John Punni said.

The church closed down its services but will still be providing mobile meals and access to its food pantry. Punni said they got the idea from another church and hope others will do something similar if they can.
